premise: A semi-circular wire frame with a radius of r is formed by connecting wires of the same material and thickness.
conclusion: The wire frame consists of a semi-circular arc and a straight line segment.

premise: The plane of the wire frame is perpendicular to the direction of the magnetic induction intensity.
conclusion: The plane of the wire frame is perpendicular to the magnetic field.

premise: Points M and N are connected to the two terminals of a direct current constant voltage power supply.
conclusion: Points M and N are connected to the power supply terminals.

premise: The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the straight part of the wire frame is F.
conclusion: The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the straight part MN is F.

premise: The force on a straight conductor of length L carrying current I in a magnetic field B is given by F = I L B.
conclusion: The force on the straight part of the wire frame is F = I (2r) B.

premise: The force on the semi-circular arc is F_{arc} = I (\pi r) B.
conclusion: The force on the semi-circular arc is F_{arc} = I (\pi r) B.

premise: The total force is the vector sum of the forces on the straight and curved parts.
conclusion: The total force is F_{total} = F + F_{arc} = I r B (2 + \pi).

premise: We know F = I (2r) B, so I r B = F / 2.
conclusion: Substitute I r B into the total force equation: F_{total} = F (1 +  rac{\pi}{2}).

premise: The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the entire wire frame is F_{total} = F (1 +  rac{\pi}{2}).
conclusion: The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the entire wire frame is (1 +  rac{2}{\pi})F.
